sen.j: 西園寺 師季（さいおんじ もろすえ、文政9年9月1日 (旧暦)（1826年10月2日） - 嘉永4年7月19日 (旧暦)（1851年8月15日））は、江戸時代後期の公卿。
sen.e: Morosue SAIONJI (October 2, 1826 - August 15, 1851) was a Court noble who lived during the late Edo period.
Morosue SAIONJI (October 2, 1826 - August 15, 1851) was Kugyo (a Court Noble) in the late Edo period.
sen.cmt: 他の西園寺ファイルとの整合性から、表現を訂正しました。
sen.e: Morosue SAIONJI (October 2, 1826 - August 15, 1851) was Kugyo (a Court Noble) in the late Edo period.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 主に仁孝天皇（120代）・孝明天皇（121代）の二帝にわたり仕えた。
sen.e: He served at the Imperial Court during the reigns of two emperors: Emperor Ninko (the one hundred-twentieth Japanese emperor) and Emperor Komei (the one hundred and twenty-first Japanese emperor).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He primarily served for the two sovereigns: the 120th Emperor Ninko and the 121st Emperor Komei.

sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 官位は正三位近衛府まで昇った。
sen.e: His final official title was Ukone no Gon no Chujo (Provisional Middle Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards) with the rank of Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank).

sen.e: He was promoted up to Shosanmi - "Ukone no Gon no Chujo" (Senior Third Rank and Provisional Middle Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards).

sen.e: He was promoted up to Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank) Ukone no Gon no Chujo (Provisional Middle Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards).
sen.cmt: 表現を変えました。

sen.j: 父は近衛府西園寺治季。
sen.e: His father was Sakone no Chujo (Middle Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards) Harusue SAIONJI.

sen.j: 室は内大臣徳大寺実堅の娘。
sen.e: His wife was a daughter of Naidaijin (Inner Minister) Sanemi TOKUDAIJI.
His wife was a daughter of Naidaijin (Minister of the Center) Sanemi TOKUDAIJI.
sen.cmt: Inner Minister→Minister of the Centerに訂正しました。

sen.j: 養子縁組に後に内閣総理大臣となる西園寺公望（徳大寺公純の子）がいる。
sen.e: He adopted Kinmochi SAIONJI (a biological son of Kinito TOKUDAIJI), who later became the prime minister.
He had an adopted child, Kinmochi SAIONJI who was a biological son of Kinito TOKUDAIJI; Kinmochi became Prime Minister later.

sen.j: 天保7年（1836年）に先代の右近衛権中将西園寺公潔が早世したために西園寺家を相続する。
sen.e: He succeeded to the head of the Saionji family in 1836 as Ukone no Gon no Chujo Kinzumi SAIONJI, the former head of the family, died young.
He became heir to the Saionji family in 1836 when the previous head of the family, Kinzumi SAIONJI of "Ukone no Gon no Chujo" died at an early age.
sen.cmt: わかりやすくするため訂正しました。

sen.j: 同年に叙爵し、以降累進して侍従・近衛府・右近衛権中将などを歴任し、弘化2年（1845年）に従三位となり公卿に列する。
sen.e: After being conferred a peerage in that year, he experienced various positions such as a chamberlain, Sakone no Gon no Shosho (Provisional Minor Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards), and Ukone no Gon no Chujo, and then he ranked among Court nobles with the rank of Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) in 1845.
sen.cmt: 原文に「近衛府」とございますが、リンク先の用語となっているようです。ウェブを確認し、「左近衛権少将」として訳出いたしました。
sen.e: In the same year, he was conferred a peerage; he took different positions, such as Chamberlain, "Sakone no Gon no Shosho" (Provisional Minor Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards) and "Ukone no Gon no Chujo;" In 1845, he became Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank), which gave him the title Kugyo.

sen.j: その翌年に正三位となったが、嘉永4年（1851年）には薨去した。
sen.e: He was granted the rank of Shosanmi in the following year, but he died in 1851.

sen.j: 実子がなく、徳大寺公純の次男の西園寺公望を養子として西園寺家を相続させた。
sen.e: Since he did not have any biological children, he adopted Kinmochi SAIONJI, the second son of Kinito TOKUDAIJI, in order that he would succeed to the head of the Saionji family.
Because he did not have any biological sons, he adopted Kinmochi who was the second son of Kinito TOKUDAIJI; Consequently, Kinmochi SAIONJI became heir to the Saionji family.

sen.j: 後に公望は内閣総理大臣・財務大臣・外務大臣 (日本)などの要職を歴任し、明治・大正・昭和に至るまで政界の重鎮として重きをなした。
sen.e: Kinmochi experienced some key posts such as the Prime Minister, the Minister of Finance, and the Minister of Foreign Affairs afterward, and he occupied an important position as a leading political figure during the Meiji, the Taisho, and the Showa periods.

Later Kinmochi assumed some important positions in the government of Japan, such as Prime Minister, Minister of Finance and Minister of Foreign Affairs; He played a role of the prominent political leader of Japan whole through the periods of Meiji, Taisho, and Showa.
